lead_paragraph: On Sept. 11, as schoolchildren across the country learned of the attack on the twin towers, there was a rush of students in Jerry Kerne's sixth-grade class asking to go to the bathroom. Actually, they just wanted to look out the hall window and see the smoking towers for themselves. Yesterday, some children in Mr. Kerne's class, at Public School 20 on the Lower East Side, recalled worrying that day that loved ones were dead, and that an attack might happen at their school. Others reported more recent concerns, like fear of reprisals against Muslim students and fear about the continuing war on terrorism. ''If we settle it with war, they're going to get angry and want to destroy New York more,'' said Alia Nicole Jimenez, 11.
abstract: New York Times 9/11 Neediest Fund has received $46.8 million in donations to date; of that, $8.7 million has been given to 10 social service agencies that use money to provide direct relief to families and individuals affected by attack on World Trade Center (M)
